original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Your dreams can show you things you didn't know you were thinking about. Many people have the same dreams, like flying or falling. These dreams often mean the same thing for everyone. But to understand what they mean for you, you need to think about what is happening in your life.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.
simplified: Wild dogs in Moscow. There are about 35,000 wild dogs in the city. Some dogs are born in the wild and others are pets that people have left behind. Some dogs live by themselves and others live in groups. Scientists studied the dogs in 2010. They found that the dogs are very good at living in the city. They know it's safer to cross the street with people. Some dogs even understand traffic lights.

original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
simplified: RJ Palacio's first book is Wonder. She wrote it after seeing a girl with a special face on the street. The book is very popular in the United States. It has won some awards. Many schools use it to talk about bullying, friendship and being different. A movie is being made. Many people are waiting to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.
simplified:
I have two pet rats. Their names are Zena and Roxy. Some people think rats are not good pets. They think they're dirty. But I know this isn't true. Rats can make great pets if you take care of them.

I used to think rats were not good pets too. But my friend Martin has rats and they are nice. They are friendly and smart. Last year, Martin's rat had babies. I saw them and I wanted two. So I got Zena and Roxy.

original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.
simplified: Cape Town can be a bad place for baboons. Some baboons get hurt or die in car accidents. Others get electrocuted when they play with electric wires. Baboons are a special kind of animal that is in danger. To help them, the city council has a team to look after them. This team, called Baboon Monitors, chases baboons out of the city or catches them and takes them to the countryside. This plan is working a little bit, but it is hard to keep baboons from coming back to the city. Baboons like to come back because they can easily find food there.

original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.
simplified: I work for a big company that helps people use computers. My boss is in America, so I do my job from home. I like this because I don't have to go to the office every day and talk to my colleagues. I work on different projects and this is good for me because I can take time off when my children need me to go to school. If I have a dentist appointment, I can also go then. But sometimes I work late into the evening and I don't eat dinner until I finish my work.

original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.
simplified:
In the 1990s, street art grew. Some artists made pictures to talk about war, inequality and unfairness. They wanted people to think about these things. Other artists made beautiful pictures. They wanted people to enjoy them.

Some artists worked in poor areas in South America. They added colour and beauty to grey city walls. They made the places look nicer.

original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.
simplified: People see many things to buy on social media, in magazines and in shop windows every day. British people are buying more clothes and shoes now than ever before. Online shopping makes it easy for people to buy things without thinking. Big brands sell cheap clothes. We can buy them and use them a few times and then throw them away.

original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.
simplified: Sam looked at the dust trail from the car going up to the Big House. The horses were moving and swishing their tails at flies. Sam waited. Mr Carter usually stayed inside unless he had to come out. Sam liked it that way. If he stayed out of trouble, he would keep his job. Mr Carter wiped the sweat from his neck. His shirt was wet and his skin was getting red from the sun.

original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
simplified: People in Berlin, Germany were angry because hunters were shooting pigs. They thought it was cruel. Hunters and people who like animals argued a lot. The city council said they would do something else. They put up fences to keep the pigs out of the city. They also made a rule that people can't feed the pigs. We will see if this works. The winters are warmer now, so there are more pigs than before.

original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.
simplified: Suzanne likes classical Greek stories. When she was a child, she liked the story of Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, the city of Athens was ruled by Crete. The people of Athens did not like this, so they rebelled. As a punishment, the king of Crete made the Athenians send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The boys and girls were put in a special place called the labyrinth. A monster called the Minotaur lived in the labyrinth and ate the boys and girls. But one boy, named Theseus, was brave and fought the Minotaur. He killed the monster. Suzanne likes Katniss Everdeen. She thinks Katniss is like a modern-day Theseus.

original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.
simplified: Zoos help people learn about animals and their homes. They also help people care for animals that are hurt or need a new home. Some zoos do important research to help animals.

original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.
simplified:
People don't want to buy too much. This is a new idea. It started in Canada many years ago. Now, people in the US are doing it too. They don't like buying too much on Black Friday and Cyber Monday. These are big shopping days in the US. 

On one day, people protest against buying too much. They cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, groups of people work together. They share things they already have. They also fix things that are broken.

original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.
simplified:
Is graffiti art or vandalism? 

Many people think it is vandalism. 
When you write or paint on public or private buildings, buses or trains, it is not allowed. 
The police can stop you and you might have to pay a fine. 
City councils are unhappy because it is expensive to clean graffiti off buildings.

original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.
simplified:
What do people in the art world think of graffiti and street art? 

More and more people in the art world think that graffiti and street art are important art. They have big shows in galleries in many cities, like Paris, London and Los Angeles. 

An American artist named Elura Emerald helped to show street art in a New York gallery in 2008. She said that artists who paint on the street are just expressing themselves and not hurting anyone. They should be happy and celebrated.

original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.
simplified: Many people have dreams every night. They have 4 to 6 dreams after they are 10 years old. This means they have 2,000 dreams every year. By the time they are 80 years old, they might have had 140,000 dreams. We forget most of our dreams, but we remember some. It's not hard to believe that a dream can happen before a real event. This can happen if the dream is about something that happens often.

original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.
simplified: The Hunger Games happens in the future. A long time ago, North America was destroyed. Now it's called Panem. Panem has 12 poor districts. They are controlled by a rich place called the Capitol. The Capitol has all the power. The districts make different things for the Capitol. District 12 is where the story starts. They make coal for everyone. A long time ago, there was a 13th district. They didn't like the Capitol, so they fought against them. The Capitol was angry and destroyed them.

original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.
simplified:
Wild animals come into cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons are coming into houses near the city to eat. They open bins and take fruit from gardens. Some baboons even go inside houses and take food from the kitchen. 

Baboons can be mean and hurt pets. Many people don't like them in the city.

original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.
simplified: Many accidents happen when a bridge is being built. These accidents often happen because the engineers make a mistake, like a wrong calculation. The bridge can break down under its own weight. This can be very bad for the people working on the bridge at the time.

original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.
simplified:
George Lucas made a famous film called Star Wars. He based his story on a special idea. This idea says that heroes go on a big journey. The journey has 17 stages. The hero starts with a normal life. But then something happens that makes them go on a big adventure.

In the film Star Wars, the hero is Luke. He lives with his aunt and uncle. They repair robots. Luke finds a message in a robot called R2D2. This message is from a princess. It is for a man named Obi-Wan Kenobi. This message makes Luke go on his big adventure.

original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.
simplified:
There is a way to stop a big rock from space from hitting Earth. It is called a PHA (Potentially Hazardous Asteroid). If one is coming towards us, we can try to move it off course.

We can use special rockets. They are very big and strong. We fire them at the asteroid. We want them to bump it off course. If the asteroid is very close to Earth, we need to do something else.

We can make the rockets carry special bombs. These bombs are very powerful. They can blow up the asteroid. This way, it will not hit Earth.

original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.
simplified:
According to Campbell, the hero first says no to the adventure. But then a helper appears and says, "Let's go!" The hero decides to go into a special place where the adventure happens. 

In Luke's story, his helper is Obi-Wan. He meets friends like Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO. But he also meets his enemy, Darth Vader, in a bad place called the Death Star.

original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.
simplified: We can use old things and they may seem useless, but they can be useful for someone else. People have found a way to make money by sharing these old things with others. They use the internet to find people who want to buy or sell second-hand things. This is called the sharing economy.

original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.
simplified: A long time ago, two people had different ideas about dreams. One idea was that things we see in our dreams are like secrets in our mind. They show us things we don't know about ourselves. A famous man called Freud said that if we understand our dreams, we can understand why we feel certain ways and why we have problems. But another person thought that dreams are just random things that happen in our brain when it is working. It is like our brain is cleaning up things from the day and then we try to make sense of it when we wake up.

original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.
simplified: I work for myself. I like being in control of my work and my time. At first, I worked from home, but it was hard to focus. There were too many things to do at home, like housework and making tea. My family wanted my attention too. So, I started working in a café near my home. However, the internet connection was not good, and I drank too much coffee. I decided to rent a desk in a shared office with other people who work for themselves. I like dressing up to go to work and focusing in an office.

original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.
simplified:
NASA wants to find more asteroids in space. They need a new telescope called NEOCam to help them find the middle-sized asteroids. This telescope can see in the dark with infrared light. If NASA gets the money, they can build it in ten years.

After they find the middle-sized asteroids, they need to figure out how to protect the Earth from the big, bad asteroids called PHAs.

original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.
simplified:
Some social media stars now tell people not to buy things. They usually show us things to buy. Now they say don't buy anything for a year. Two friends in Canada did this. They wanted to buy only food for a year. 

First, they learned to live without buying things like phones, clothes, and home things. They did this for three months. Next, they stopped using services like haircuts, eating out, and car petrol. They saved a lot of money, $55,000, in one year.

original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.
simplified: Pi likes learning about different religions. His family is Hindu, but he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Pi says he wants to be all three - Hindu, Muslim and Christian. His family and teachers ask him to choose just one, but Pi says he just wants to love God. So, they let him decide for himself.

original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!
simplified: Some people think writing about their dreams can help them have more interesting dreams. They call these dreams lucid dreams. In a lucid dream, you know you're dreaming and you can change what's happening. So, you can turn a bad dream into a good one or make the story of your dream happen the way you want it to. This way, instead of just thinking about what your dreams mean, you can make your own dreams.

original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.
simplified: People think they're helping by giving old clothes to charity. But charity shops can't sell them all. The clothes people buy today are not good enough to be sold again tomorrow. They're often very cheap and not good quality. So, people don't want to buy them used. Many old clothes are thrown away. Some charities send old clothes to other countries, but this causes more problems.

original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.
simplified:
Meagan McGrath from Canada has done many adventures. She climbed big mountains on every continent. She rode a bike across Canada and ran a long race in the hot Sahara Desert. She also went skiing to the South Pole. 

On her first day, Meagan fell into a big block of ice and had to be helped out. Many people would stop doing the trip at this point. But Meagan decided to keep going. She walked for 40 days with a big bag behind her. The bag had a tent and food for her trip. She had to walk through very cold weather and sometimes it snowed a lot.

original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.
simplified: Blek le Rat paints pictures on the walls of Paris. He started by painting rats. Now he paints pictures to make people think about big problems. He paints pictures of people without homes in big cities. He wants people to think about how to help these people.

original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.
simplified: Some cities let artists paint on walls. They have special areas for this. In Taiwan, artists can paint in these areas. They can write on the walls too. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city council lets some artists paint on the subway trains.

original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.
simplified: Faith47 is from Cape Town. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals. She likes to explore different places. Her paintings are on pavements, in old factories and on old cars. She likes this because her paintings don't last long. The weather or cleaners will soon take them away. She thinks this is like life. Life is always changing. Old things end and new things start.

original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.
simplified: Gabriela used to work in a place where bosses made the big decisions. People respected the bosses and didn't often disagree. Now she works with a team in Sweden. They make decisions together with their bosses. Their bosses help and encourage them. They want people to think for themselves and make their own decisions.

original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.
simplified: Gabriela talked to her team about their feelings about her. She wanted to know what they thought. They said they didn't like it when she told them what to do. They wanted to do things on their own and make new ideas. They said it made them feel like Gabriela didn't trust them. They also said they were used to making changes to the plans. They thought Gabriela was getting upset when they did this, but they were just doing it the way they always did.

original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.
simplified: Os Gêmeos are two brothers from São Paulo. They are very good at painting. They paint big pictures on buildings. Their pictures are very colourful. Sometimes, they need big machines to help them paint. In 2007, they painted a whole castle in Scotland.

original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!
simplified: People have been writing and drawing on walls for a long time. In old times, people in Africa and Europe painted animals and people in caves. We can still see graffiti on old buildings in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In a town called Pompeii, archaeologists found many messages written on the walls in a language called Latin. These messages were about love, politics and even magic.

original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.
simplified: Many people do. Every year, many people try to climb the biggest mountain or walk across a big land. They use special tools like a GPS and a phone that sends messages from space. Some people like nature and use their travels to help people know about the environment. They want to help the Earth. Some people want to help others and collect money for good causes.

original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
simplified:
The world is a violent place, but there is some good news. Between World War II and 1990, there were many wars that killed many people. However, today, countries are mostly getting along better than before. But there is a problem - terrorism is getting worse. 

In the past, more soldiers than civilians were killed in wars. But now, many more civilians are being killed. However, there is some good news for civilians. They are less likely to be killed in wars than before. Also, the number of people being murdered is going down. In 2000, 8 people out of 100,000 were being murdered. In 2015, this number went down to 5.3.

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.
simplified: Wasfia works to help people in her country, Bangladesh. She wants women and girls to be treated fairly. But some projects that help them often stop and the women are left with nothing. Wasfia wants to change this. She combines her two loves, climbing mountains and helping people, to make a difference. She started climbing when she worked in Tibet and Nepal. Bangladesh is a flat country, so most people have never seen a mountain. Wasfia's project is helping people understand that women in Bangladesh deserve respect.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.
simplified: Most people think that countries with less money are very poor and unhappy. They think the people who run these countries are bad and there is no chance for things to get better. But, actually, this is not true. Something good is happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have become richer and are no longer poor. Also, every year, 6 million fewer children die from sickness. More girls are going to school and many people now have clean water.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified:
Some managers give feedback that is positive and negative. They say something good, then something bad, and then something good again. This is called a "sandwich".

But when they do this all the time, the good things they say don't seem true. The employees think the manager is just being nice and hiding the bad things. This makes the good feedback less important.

We should give feedback that is only good. This way, we can help people do better.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
simplified: We already have machines that can kill people, like drones and robots. They do this with a little help from humans. But what if machines could decide who to kill on their own? This would be very bad for us. We need to be careful about what we ask machines to do.

original: Overall, more people are learning English than the other languages combined and English is spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.
simplified: More people learn English than any other language. English is spoken in many countries. But Chinese has more people who speak it from birth. There is no clear connection between how many people speak a language from birth and how many people learn it. However, there is a connection between how many people learn a language and how many countries it is spoken in.

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.
simplified: My boss stops me and says we need to talk about my work on the recent project. I'm worried all weekend about what I did wrong. When I go to her office on Monday, she starts by saying I did a good job on the project. I think maybe this is just the first nice thing she has to say before she tells me what's wrong. I know this is called the feedback sandwich. She says something nice, then tells me what she really wants to say, and then says something nice again.

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
simplified: Bruce Springsteen's rock album Born in the USA has happy music, but the words are sad. The music is catchy, but the songs tell about people who work hard and are unhappy. They don't have money or fame. The song Glory Days is about people in a small town who remember when they were young. They had a lot of opportunities. The song Downbound Train is about a young man who loses his job and his life gets worse. The singer might be singing about people he knows and his own life if he hadn't become famous. This album shows how good the singer is.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified:
Lewis wants to protect the ocean. He wants 10% of the ocean to be safe areas for animals. This is up from 3% now.

Lewis has seen the ocean get hurt. He has swum over coral reefs that are white and dead. He has seen the ocean floor in the Red Sea. It's like a desert with no life and lots of plastic.

Lewis thinks the ocean can get better if we give it space. But time is running out. If we don't take care of the ocean, we might have a big problem soon.

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born on the housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences throughout the UK.
simplified:
Terrie Sharp is a famous writer. She has won two big awards for her stories. She was born on a big housing project in Glasgow. Glasgow is a city in Scotland. It's a place with a lot of crime.

Terrie learned to be careful and stay safe. She knew how to open car doors with a knife. But she didn't use this skill for bad things. She used it to write her books. Now, she talks on TV and at writing events in the UK.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified:
Things are not getting worse every day. We are living better lives. 

We are living longer. We are healthier. We are freer. We are happier. 

But there is a problem. Some people do not believe in using our brains to make good choices. They do not believe in science. They want to make people angry at others. They do not want people to trust each other. 

This is a danger to our democracy and our way of working together.

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified:
In old horror films, people were in trouble and couldn't call for help. Now it's hard to believe that. Because we all have mobile phones. So, what do horror film makers do? They make sure there's no phone signal. 

If you're a hero in a horror film, you'll often be in a situation where you really need to call for help. But it won't work. Your phone won't have any signal or the battery will be dead. That's just what happens.

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
simplified:
Big Mike, the Gros Michel banana, was a big problem for banana farmers in Central America. They had a lot of bananas to sell, but people stopped buying them because they got a disease. 

Now, the Cavendish banana is in trouble too. It's a sweet banana that's easy to transport. People like it a lot. But it's also getting sick. 

In the past, banana farmers used a special way to grow bananas. They took a piece from a banana stem and made a new plant. They put many of these new plants close together in fields. This made it easy to grow and sell a lot of bananas.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified:
Most spiders have venom to help them catch food. But only 25 kinds of spiders have venom that can hurt people. Most spider bites are not serious. 

Some spiders, like the Sydney funnel-web spider, can be bad. But doctors have medicine now to help. 

Be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. They can get angry if they feel scared. They throw out hair that can hurt if it gets in your eyes or skin.

original: This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.
simplified:
This kind of horror movie was very popular a long time ago. It usually starts with a group of young people who are happy. But in the end, everyone dies except one girl.

The girl is often shy and weak at the beginning. But by the end, she becomes strong and clever. Most of the time, the last girl survives and wins.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified:
If we want to know where our ability to speak many words came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This is not just about how big our brains are, but also about what else our brains can do. When and why our brains developed in this way is also important. But there are very few clues in our physical history. The things our ancestors left behind, like tools, do not tell us what they could say.

One thing we can see in the bones of early humans is how their mouth, throat, and tongue developed. About 100,000 years ago, humans could make many different sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess how early humans communicated.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified:
Girls should do arts and humanities, not maths and physics. This is what society says. But it's not true. We need to see more women doing science jobs. 

Cartoons and stories show men as scientists, inventors and astronauts. They are often shown as a bit strange. The media says scientists are not good with people and work alone. But this is not true. 

If girls saw women doing science jobs, they would be more confident and feel better about science.

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.
simplified: The Scallion is a free newspaper for students. It comes out every week and is given to students in university buildings. Many students read it - about 10,000 students. The newspaper is made by students. A survey shows that students and staff like the newspaper because it is fun, interesting and good for their jobs. However, making the newspaper is expensive. Some students cannot easily get a copy because they have to go to the university to get one. Also, many copies end up on the floor and make a mess.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified: At Girox Foods, many employees leave every year. This is 12 per cent of all employees. Most companies have a lower rate of 7 per cent. This report wants to find out why many employees are not happy at work. We will also suggest ways to make work better for employees and keep them.

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
simplified: The more connected we are, the more alone we feel. I don't think this is a big issue for me. I grew up without technology. I know how to be alone and it's okay to be alone. But for people under 20, it's different. They are always sending messages. They never feel alone. They might not know how to enjoy their own company. They are also learning to talk through messages. This means they don't learn how to talk to people in real life.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: You are a good teacher. You are kind to your students. Your students like you.

original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Your dreams can give you clues about your thoughts and feelings. Some common dreams, like flying or falling, have the same meaning for many people. However, to understand what these dreams mean to you, you need to think about what's happening in your life and how you're feeling.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.
simplified: There are about 35,000 wild dogs living in Moscow. Some of these dogs were born in the wild, while others were pets that were left by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in groups. Scientists studied the dogs in 2010 and found that they have adapted well to living in the city. They know it's safer to cross the road with people and some dogs seem to understand traffic lights.

original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
simplified: RJ Palacio's first book is Wonder. RJ Palacio wrote on her website that she got the idea for the book after seeing a girl with a special face on the street one day. The book has been very popular in the United States and has won several awards. Many schools use it to talk about bullying, friendship and being different. A film version is being made. People are waiting to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.
simplified: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows people often think rats are dirty, but they're not. She has to explain this a lot. She used to think rats were not nice pets, but then her friend Martin showed her his rats. They were very friendly and smart. Chloe was surprised. Last year, Martin's rat had babies. Chloe decided she wanted two of them, so she got Zena and Roxy.

original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.
simplified: Cape Town can be a difficult place for baboons. They sometimes get hurt in car accidents or are electrocuted when they play with electric wires. Baboons are a threatened species, and the city council wants to protect them and stop them from coming into conflict with people. To do this, the city council has hired a team of Baboon Monitors. Their job is to move baboons out of the city or catch them and let them go in the countryside. This plan has worked a bit, but it's hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city because they know they can find food there easily.

original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.
simplified: I work for a big IT company. They are based in the States, so I work from home. I don't have to travel to the office or talk to my colleagues all the time. I work on projects and can choose my own hours. This is good for me because I can take time off when my children need me to be at school or when I have a doctor's appointment. But sometimes, I work too late at night. I might even skip dinner to finish my work.

original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.
simplified: In the 1990s, street art became very popular around the world. Some artists used their work to make people think about important issues like war, inequality and unfair treatment. They wanted to make people aware of these problems. Other street artists focused on creating beautiful and attractive art. In South America, many artists worked in poor areas, adding colour and beauty to grey city walls.

original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.
simplified: People are constantly shown things to buy on social media, in magazines and in shop windows. British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. It's easy to buy things online without thinking about it. Some big brands sell cheap clothes that can be worn a few times and then thrown away.

original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.
simplified: Sam looked at the dust on the road from Mr Carter's car as it drove up to the Big House. The horses were annoyed with flies and didn't care that their owner was coming. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't often come out here. Sam was happy about this. It meant he would have a job for longer. Mr Carter wiped the sweat from his neck. The wet patches on his shirt looked like shapes in a map. His skin was getting red in the sun. This was because he usually worked indoors and made money while other people did the work.

original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
simplified: Many people in Berlin, Germany are unhappy about shooting pigs. They think it's cruel. There are disagreements between people who hunt and those who love animals. The city council decided to do something different. They put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. We'll have to wait and see if this works. It might be difficult because the pigs have more babies now that the winters are warmer.

original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.
simplified:
Suzanne Collins, the author of The Hunger Games, was inspired by classical Greek mythology. One of her favourite stories as a child was about a hero named Theseus. 

In this story, the city of Athens was ruled by Crete. The people of Athens were unhappy and decided to rebel. As a punishment, the king of Crete, Minos, made the Athenians send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. These young people were thrown into a big maze called the Labyrinth, where a monster called the Minotaur lived. The Minotaur was very hungry and ate the youths. But one of the youths, Theseus, was brave and fought the Minotaur. He killed the monster and saved his friends. 

Suzanne Collins thinks of Katniss Everdeen as a strong and brave character like Theseus.

original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.
simplified: Zoos bring people and animals together. This can help people learn about conservation and care for animals and their homes. Some zoos give a safe place to animals that were treated badly in circuses or abandoned pets. Zoos also do important research on animals, like how they behave and how to make them healthy.

original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.
simplified: A new trend is against buying too much. It's called the 'buy nothing' trend. This idea started in Canada in the early 1990s and then spread to the US. In the US, it was against spending too much money on Black Friday and Cyber Monday during the Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day, people protest and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, people in Buy Nothing groups exchange and fix things they already own.

original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.
simplified: Many people think it's vandalism because it's writing or painting on public or private property without permission. In many countries, it's against the law. Street artists who do it can be stopped by the police and have to pay fines. City councils are unhappy because it's expensive to clean up graffiti on buildings, buses and trains.

original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.
simplified: The art world is starting to see graffiti and street art as a valuable art form. There have been big exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. In 2008, an American artist named Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition in New York. She said that street artists should be appreciated and celebrated because they are just expressing themselves, not hurting anyone.

original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.
simplified: Most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten. This means they have as many as 2,000 dreams per year. By the time they reach 80 years old, the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95-99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not surprising that sometimes a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it. This can happen especially if the dream is about something that happens often in everyday life.

original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.
simplified: Around the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became popular. One idea was that things we see in our dreams show us things our conscious mind doesn't know. Sigmund Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are saying, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. The other idea said that dreams are just random things happening in the brain while it's sorting out memories and things we did during the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and turn them into a story.

original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. First, they learned how to live without buying things like electronics, clothes, and household items for three months. Then, they stopped using services like haircuts, eating out, and buying petrol for their cars. After one year, they had saved $55,000.

original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. simplified: Pi is interested in different religions. His family is Hindu, but he also makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. simplified: Some people think that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. Lucid dreams are dreams where you know you're dreaming and you can control what happens in the dream. This means you'll be making your own dreams instead of just trying to understand what they mean.

original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.
simplified: Blek le Rat started painting rats in Paris. Now, he paints pictures to make people think about social problems. He paints homeless people in cities to remind people about homelessness.

original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. original: Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. original: In 2010, the planetary defence team at NASA had identified and logged 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth measuring 1km wide. original: Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. simplified:

original: The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. simplified: Two men looked to the north. They could see a long way. The fences were hard to see from where they stood. It was hard for a teenager to run away. Sam looked at a big horse. It was kicking its hooves. Could the boy ride a horse? Sam thought about it. There was trouble for someone who knew how to ride. original: Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.
simplified:

original: Having climbed Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To increase the challenge, Gerlinde climbs without using oxygen tanks. original: If we look around us at the things we have purchased at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked trendy despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storeroom.

original: Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or insight. original: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. simplified: Gabriela was having trouble with her team. She sent an email to her Swedish manager about the problems. original: Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs so those dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. original: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. original: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. In Britain, people spend a lot of money on new clothes each year. They spend more than £1,000 on average, which is about four per cent of their income.

Also, people are spending money they don't have and buying things they don't need. As a result, a lot of clothes are thrown away. Every year, Britain gets rid of 300,000 tons of clothing, most of which ends up in landfill sites.

original: Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land.
